comments.commentBody: Maybe, but I have my doubts that forcing people who don't educate themselves before voting - or simply don't care one way or another - into voting is going to improve things. Not that I have any solutions, just don't think compulsory voting is the answer. Perhaps direct, nationwide elections that replace the skewed-toward-the-fringe primary + electoral college system will do the trick?
It is my understanding that there is a financial penalty in Australia for not voting.  That would be helpful here.
Compulsory voting would take us a long way toward needed, healthy compromise necessary in successful governance. Neither party would have to kowtow to the fringe.

"No, the real structural problem is in our political system, which has been warped and paralyzed by the power of a small, wealthy minority."

It's not just the political system. The plutocracy's stealthy coup d'etat has also poisoned the judicial system. Federal and state courts have been increasingly packed by judges who rule for the interests of the plutocracy at every opportunity; a corrupted Supreme Court has cemented the plutocracy's advantage in place with the Citizens United ruling, which gives it the right to spend its unlimited wealth in buying elections and politicians.

The peasants beginning to stir via the Occupy movement. If Occupy isn't heeded (and believe me, every Occupy activist represents tens or perhaps hundreds, of the rest of us), we will descend into a new dark age in which corporate, political and judicial power are one and the same - which fits a definition of Fascism.

Actually you are pretty much correct here. The gov't subsidies to smaller airports & to airlines to keep them flying into the smaller markets was eliminated about 3 or 4 years ago. A lot of it was considered politial at the time (of course). We are seeing the continue fallout.

How is denying decent, cost-effective air travel to American citizens "...a good thing?" Back in the 1800's, folks lving out west "in the middle of nowhere" had better train service then than those same places have air service now! So a slowly degenerating civil transportation system is good, right?

Air travel is, and has always been, about TIME! The air transprtation system, deregulated by the GOP in the 1980's, was the beginning of the end of air transportation, and the Saudi Arabia, after destroying New York's Twin Towers, finished the job the GOP started. By making the system so horrendous and foolish with it's high-school diploma TSA Storm Troopers molesting the very old, small children and everyone in between with it's "security theater" and naked-body-scanners.  The arabs have not stopped laughing or backslapping each other since. I don't believe the air transportation will survive much longer. So you are correct...got to see a man about a horse.

I used to fly regularly. The last time I did was three years ago. Between the never-ending fees airlines are imposing in addition to the price of the ticket, and rising fares, I've switched to Amtrak. Traveling between Illinois and New England, where most of my immediate family lives, it means an overnight trip each way, but it's far less expensive. I'm fortunate enough to live in a city well-served by Amtrak. What about those places that don't have that choice?

Even in the 70's and 80's things were not so good. The published schedules looked much better than the actual performance. We had two Lebanon, NH - Boston, MA "competing" shuttle carriers. Apart from the predictable weather issues, it was amazing how many "mechanical" cancellations we had. (This kind of cancellation did not then affect "on-time performance" ratings because the regulatory thought was that no airline should ever have an incentive to fly in a marginally safe situation.)

I recall sitting at the "gate" in Boston's Logan Airport (rows of chairs on either side of a hallway) staring a the lonely couple across from me, the only other passengers in sight. "I foresee a mechanical issue," I said. They nodded, apparently as experienced as I. Two minutes later, a gate official told us that we had been re-booked on a flight on the other airline because of--you guessed it!--"mechanical issues". At least in those days, the long forgotten and much beloved "Rule 380" (or 320 or 340 or maybe even 420) guaranteed the re-booking for any class of ticket using any carrier at no cost to the passenger. (The original carrier had some narrow time frame in which it held exclusive re-booking rights.)

Bottom line: It was NEVER easy to fly from a small airport. One pays a price for the small-town choice. For some, the bucolic benefits outweigh the costs. For others, like spunky Mary Richards, the big city. beckons.

The drive from Greenville is beautiful. But you can go non-stop from Newark to AVL for $350, which isn't bad. Delta used to fly direct from LGA-AVL, but that flight has disappeared. That being said, transferring is CLT is very easy.

did you consider going out of BTV or BDL instead of LEB? I live in WRJ and used to use LEB (15 min) all the time, but after the attacks in 01 service to PHL got cancelled and I began using MHT. (95 min) Now most of my destinations are non-stop only from BOS so I go there (125 min) or BDL (135 min).
Actually, A.S., direct doesn't mean non-stop. It means you don't change planes.

Americans should have a CHOICE - an ALTERNATIVE.

Right now, the only choice is you fly or drive. A high-speed rail system creates a third alternative. Given the hassles of security, flying has become a contact sport. Unless you are flying more than 750 miles, the time spent is not worth the effort. Short distances (less than 200 miles) is good for driving. In between is a big hole that could be serviced by rail.

(Buses could service this middle ground. Of course, they would end up on the same crumbling roads/highways and be stuck in the same traffic along with everyone else. Fail to see the point.)

In many countries, there is only ONE regulated airline. The U.S. has 5 major airlines.

Does that sound efficient to you? Five sets of gates, five fleets of airplanes, five groups of over-paid executives and five computer systems. All similar but with duplicated overhead.

THIS IS STUPID!
Can you say "High-speed Rail?"

I have twice used Angie's list. The comfort level from the start is higher because you are more informed in your choices. he deals they send to members are great. I bought two hours of plumbing work for $100 (plus parts) and got a couple of needed things done. The jobs were well done.

Compare what a successful business like Angie's list provides and how many benefit by its existence to that of a Bain or the CDO/CWS shops that we bailed out.

What you say is a good reminder that we the American voters (and I'm one too) have *asked* for this.  As long as we play Uncle Tom to the Simon Legrees in the 1% and *vote* for coddling the rich while whipping the poor and middle classes, then we largely have ourselves to blame for this mess.  After all, it's (still) a free country, and our votes DO count.  A vote for the GOP is a vote against yourself and your family.

I've had terrible experiences with Angie's list.  The problem is the service providers know which customers wrote their reviews and some people are too worried to say what they really thought of the work.  Also in my case the service provider did a terrible job and offered to refund my money if I didn't write a bad review, which I agreed to.  It's not as unbiased a system as some would have you believe.

For what it's worth, Angie's List, even though it costs a little, is a much safer place to hire contractors because you have the benefit of reviews from former customers, and you are hiring licensed and insured people. You really don't want someone on a ladder at your house without proper insurance.

But the thrust of the story -- sad. Paul Krugman may be right -- what we are experiencing is a depression. The last one of these, it took a world war -- the ultimate government jobs program -- to rebuild the middle class and get people back on their feet. Now we have a political party whose only answer to unemployment (only answer to anything, really) is to cut taxes on the millionaires and billionaires so they can be even richer. Why so many people are actually buying that is quite a mystery.

Maybe, but I have my doubts that forcing people who don't educate themselves before voting - or simply don't care one way or another - into voting is going to improve things. Not that I have any solutions, just don't think compulsory voting is the answer. Perhaps direct, nationwide elections that replace the skewed-toward-the-fringe primary + electoral college system will do the trick?

Such a vast wealth gap between the top few vs even educated people with decent jobs who work every day--this is the point, and shows evidence of a diseased economy. No one is advocating complete equality--that is a straw man used to exaggerate the argument. It's almost paranoid to suggest that fair taxation will destroy our democracy and productivity. Look at the 50s and 60s for evidence of how a fairer society motivated millions of people and lifted them up to middle class status.

Basic security is necessary to moral decency and law and order--which should appeal to conservatives. What destroys incentives is unfairness and lack of opportunity, not taxation. Ironically, where extreme collectivism is found is in our top business corporate concentrations of wealth. These are 'unions' of capital, or you might say 'communes' of capital? They collectivize to leverage power over the country, extract the wealth of the majority. and dominate our congress with big money. How much more 'collectivist can you get?

Joseph: my 4 kids, my wife, and I agreed that we would pay for their undergrad degrees. And we did. After college, they take care of themselves for the most part. I don't feel any pain if I can't give them money at this point in their lives. And I'm still happy that I drove 50 miles to be there for lunch with the parents on more than one occasion. Peace. (let's not get into a tit for tat. I'm done.)

Norwegian Wood is my all time favorite of their songs.

Elegant grid, Silky smooth.  I had some trouble parsing ODERNEISSE Line.  RUBBERSOUL was my favorite Beatles album - Norwegian Wood, In My Life, You Won't See Me, Girl... - easy to study by.  Loved JAWSOFLIFE.

We live in a time of paradox.  We have an extraordinary amount of information available to us, but many citizens are convinced that the majority of legitimate news outlets have a liberal bias.  These citizens don't consider an alternate view because the alternate view challenges their own conclusions.  Those conclusions have been seared by a conviction in biblical inerrancy.  So, the Republicans are aligned through presumed and unquestioned shared family values and faith, acceptance of the nonsense about government being "the problem," and a simplistic view of what creates jobs.  I think the reality is that the religious views aren't shared, and there is no intention of creating jobs, and that the government services we enjoy today are in danger of extinction.

Unfortunately the Republican Party has done a very successful job of persuading a substantial segment of American working - class whites that the G.O.P. stands for their key values (i.e. God-guns-no gays-no immigrants).

Regrettably, this group has also fallen hook-line and sinker for the old canard that the Dems. are 'tax and spend liberals' (this millennium's code phrase for 'commies') whose profligacy has purportedly driven the country to the verge of bankruptcy.

These voters, like most voters (indeed, per Kahnemann and Tversky, like most people) have a strong preference for a clear, simple, black-and-white story-line.

So it's not surprising that these voters haven't spent the time and effort to appreciate that the increase in the deficit is in large measure the consequence of private sector misdeeds that resulted in the collapse of the real-estate market.

Mind you, it is nonetheless surprising that these voters still support a measure that directly deprives them of jobs and benefits, namely cuts in government spending.

If it is so obvious that the republican party has become dominated by the very wealthy and so partisan they put their own interest ahead of the welfare of America as a whole, why than is this Presidential election, by all accounts, a close race.  Is it because, Obama is black and racism still runs rampant in the US? Big money wins elections? Social values have become more important then political or economic issues? The voting public is uneducated, misinformed and prejudiced? I cannot understand how any middle or lower class, working American can even consider voting Republican, a party which over the last few decades has become dominated by extremists, the wealthy, and religious fanatics.

This is a realistic assessment of the problem situation and it is an acute analysis and description of the reality that currently confronts us.

The well-monied interests - persons and corporations - have indeed become citizens of the world and as such should be highly taxed accordingly, inasmuch as they have chosen to reside in this country.

Let them leave and move elsewhere and thus come to find out what real taxation happens to be. Having lived in Denmark for two years at one time, I can assure everyone that their society is far above our society and they pay very high taxes to produce that good result.

The well-monied interests in this country want to have it both ways and the conservatives and Republicans are very happy to accommodate them.
I describe the behavior of the well-monied interests and their world view as being simply traitorous. They have become traitors to our democratic way of life and should suffer the consequences accordingly.
Shape up and support our Common Good .......... or leave and go elsewhere. Africa and the Middle East would love to have you - just stay off the streets.

I'd love to believe that the people will bring the reckoning to the party that has caused so much of our democratic malfunction. But the truth is that no matter how bad things get for the 99%, there will be enough ignorant and intransigent voters to keep the same fact denying obstructionist party in control of enough votes to stymie any changes to our failing democracy.
Exactly. Ignorance can be fixed but stupid is forever.

Sir, Take your threat of French Revolution and stuff it. What you wish to loot is already gone.

For my part, I long ago put a significant portion of my wealth in gold Krugerrands, cash in Swiss francs, and equity holdings purchased across a global distribution in local exchanges with native currencies. All at a significant discount to current prices. Diversified my real estate with purchases of nice homes in the Carribean and in Italy. You can confiscate the one I own in the States. It is the largest, bought off a foreclosure, but that may be the price to pay for liberty. When your pathetic little revolution comes, I will be long gone, along with many thousands of others like me, as well as a disproportionate share of the wealth that you so malevolently covet.

As they used to say in Europe many years ago, "Comes the revolution." And if things go as they have for the past two decades, the revolution will come.

When the citizenry finally realizes their safety net is gone, when the family heirlooms have to be sold in order to eat, and when retirement is no long an option, there will be a day of reckoning.

The politicians in office at that time will be the targets of unrest and revolt as it may be. They will be fortunate that in this country this revolt will probably not be violent, but there is no guarantee that it will not.

If you do not want a Marxist revolution, then you better fix the system. Most people today do not realize how close the country came to one in 1930, but look back and see that the national guard was called out to suppress strikers for instance.

There is a large group of citizens who will get what they are asking for, and they will not like it. But you can not cure stupid as the saying goes. They have to experience the folly of their ideology. Unfortunately the rest of us will suffer also.

When was your "my day"? Mine began about 1948 in a prep school and I found some of my courses dull and uninspiring with another half of them too opaque and incomprehensible. So I decided that the summer between my sophmore and junior year would be occupied with further credits.Therefore, I chose Civics and Sociology; and a "city school" other than a suburban prep. I don't recall my parents ever asking why I chose those subjects; the school was a given because you went where they offered to be open in the summer months.
I'd hazard a guess that a vast majority of that 40% doesn't even know what "liberal" means - except they think it's a bad thing...

I would not be too sure that it is the ignorant masses that have caught us unprepared. It presently appears to me that it is the privileged who attended elite universities because of independent wealthy families whose lives were spent in exclusive enclaves unbothered by the ideas of "others".

Brilliant! Such a cogent subject, so incisively and precisely tackled! Thank you for reminding us of how crucial it is to be educated in civic matters.  Certainly, the present state of affairs in this regard is more than shocking; it is truly frightening.  I hope your article gets discussed in high schools and colleges all around the country, to raise the consciousness of young people about the dangers of civic illiteracy!  Bravo for this piece!
